<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>

<target_code>
Here is the code of alloc:
```c
static int alloc(void)
{
	void *ptr;

	ptr = metal_allocate_memory(1000);
	if (!ptr) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_DEBUG, "failed to allocate memory\n");
		return errno;
	}

	metal_free_memory(ptr);

	return 0;
}
```
</target_code>

#define metal_log(level, fmt, __VA_ARGS__) ({if(_metal.common.log_handler&&level<=_metal.common.log_level)_metal.common.log_handler(level,metal_fmt(fmt),##__VA_ARGS__);\
})

explanation: I inspected the provided code and found no direct uses of any <string.h> functions (memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, strspn). The alloc function only calls metal_allocate_memory and metal_free_memory (memory allocation/deallocation), which are not string.h functions in the shown code. The only locations that could potentially involve string-handling operations are the logging macro and its invocation because the macro expands to a call that passes metal_fmt(fmt) to a log handler; metal_fmt (not defined here) might employ string functions. Therefore I flagged the macro definition and its call site for investigation. All other fragments do not reference <string.h> functions and thus do not need investigation for MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17.
